G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19..proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter under G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1,.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the incident giving rise to this claim occurred in Newton, Massachusetts, within the jurisdiction of this Court.

Newton Ordinance \u00a7 11.4.proposition: Newton Park prominently displays signs requiring all dogs to be kept on leashes pursuant to Newton Ordinance § 11.4 and Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 140, Section 155.

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 140,.proposition: Newton Park prominently displays signs requiring all dogs to be kept on leashes pursuant to Newton Ordinance § 11.4 and Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 140, Section 155.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant’s actions were in violation of the reasonable care standard set forth in Massachusetts law, including the principles articulated in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (affirming a landowner’s duty to lawful visitors) and Bonner v. Sudbury, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 1102 (2013) (addressing the liability of dog owners for their failure to control pets).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case that abolishes the rigid invitee/licensee distinction and imposes a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners to lawful entrants. Although the excerpt provided is only a concurrence and focuses on trespassers, the case as a whole supports the proposition that Massachusetts law requires landowners to exercise reasonable care toward lawful visitors; it does not, however, address dog‑owner liability. Thus, it is accurate authority for the “reasonable care to lawful visitors” portion of the proposition, but not for the dog‑control aspect (which comes from Bonner).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: [From the full opinion, not shown in the excerpt]: “We hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees should be abolished, and that the duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances.”

Bonner v. Sudbury, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 110.raw_text: Bonner v. Sudbury, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 1102 (2013)
Bonner v. Sudbury, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 110.proposition: Defendant’s actions were in violation of the reasonable care standard set forth in Massachusetts law, including the principles articulated in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (affirming a landowner’s duty to lawful visitors) and Bonner v. Sudbury, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 1102 (2013) (addressing the liability of dog owners for their failure to control pets).

Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.raw_text: Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262 (1986)
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was the proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries, as established under Massachusetts negligence law, including Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 262 (1986) (addressing foreseeability and proximate cause in negligence claims).
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.support_reasoning: The opinion does mention that negligence requires that the defendant’s failure to use due care be the ‘direct and proximate cause’ of the plaintiff’s injury, but the case does not substantively analyze or develop Massachusetts law on foreseeability or proximate cause. The appellate issues concern comparative negligence, adequacy of jury instructions, sufficiency of evidence of plaintiff’s negligence, and consortium claims—not whether the defendant’s breach was the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Thus, citing Morgan v. Lalumiere as authority specifically on foreseeability and proximate cause is overstating its role.
Morgan v. Lalumiere, 22 Mass. App. Ct. 2.relevant_excerpt:
“A defendant is negligent when he fails to use due care with respect to the plaintiff to whom he owes a duty of care and his failure to use such care is the direct and proximate cause of the injury or damage to the plaintiff.

“We are now down to four elements of negligence from what I have just said, first, there must be a duty owed by the defendants to the plaintiff; secondly, the defendants violated or breached that particular duty; and three, the plaintiff must suffer injury or damage; and four, the injury or damage must be directly related to and caused by the defendants’ breach of duty.”

Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745 (1984)..proposition: The leash laws at issue create a legal duty on the part of dog owners to maintain control of their dogs, as recognized in Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745 (1984).
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745 (1984)..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses statutory duties relating to intoxicated motorists, not leash laws or duties of dog owners. The court’s analysis of duty is grounded in motor vehicle and intoxication statutes and the special relationship between police and the motoring public, with no reference to animal control or leash statutes. Therefore, Irwin v. Ware does not provide authority for the proposition that leash laws create a legal duty on dog owners to control their dogs.
Irwin v. Ware, 392 Mass. 745 (1984)..relevant_excerpt: “Just as the duty of the defendants in Adamian and Michnik-Zilberman was rooted, at least in part, in statutory responsibilities, so the proper conduct of public law enforcement personnel with regard to intoxicated motor vehicle operators is provided by several statutes.… We conclude that there is a special relationship between a police officer who negligently fails to remove an intoxicated motorist from the highway, and a member of the public who suffers injury as a result of that failure.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure his dog and prevent it from charging at Plaintiff was a substantial factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries, as further supported in Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos concerns premises liability for slip-and-fall injuries on snow and ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction under Massachusetts law. It does not involve animals, dog behavior, control of dogs, or causation analysis in an animal-attack or dog-charge context. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a defendant’s failure to secure a dog and prevent it from charging was a substantial factor in causing a plaintiff’s injuries.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards.” (457 Mass. at 369)

Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929)..proposition: Massachusetts law holds dog owners strictly responsible for injuries caused by their dogs when the owner fails to comply with applicable leash statutes, as noted in Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929).
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929)..support_reasoning: The opinion in Maillet v. Mininno interprets and applies G.L. c. 140, § 155, which imposes liability on dog owners or keepers for injuries caused by their dogs, but it does not discuss leash laws or failure to comply with leash statutes as a basis for liability. The case focuses on whether the defendants could be jointly liable as owners/keepers and on issues of pleading and proof of ownership/keeping, not on strict responsibility arising from violation of leash requirements. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about noncompliance with leash statutes creating strict liability.
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929)..relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff was bitten by a dog. G. L. c. 140, § 155, provides: 'The owner or keeper of a dog shall be liable in tort to a person injured by it in double the amount of damages sustained by him.' She brought action, thereunder, against Agostino Mininno and his wife Rachele; and declared against them in one count alleging that 'the defendants were the owners or keepers' of the dog."

Ferreira v. Strack, 652 N.E.2d 811 (Mass.raw_text: Ferreira v. Strack, 652 N.E.2d 811 (Mass. App. Ct. 1995).
Ferreira v. Strack, 652 N.E.2d 811 (Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence per se under Massachusetts law interpreting violations of public safety statutes, such as in Ferreira v. Strack, 652 N.E.2d 811 (Mass. App. Ct. 1995).
Ferreira v. Strack, 652 N.E.2d 811 (Mass.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Ferreira v. Strack, 652 N.E.2d 811 (Mass. App. Ct. 1995), and it does not concern Massachusetts law or negligence per se based on violations of public safety statutes. Instead, it is an Illinois appellate decision addressing governmental duty to maintain roadways, intended users, proximate cause, and summary judgment under the Illinois Tort Immunity Act. It neither applies Massachusetts negligence-per-se doctrine nor treats a statutory violation as negligence per se, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Ferreira v. Strack, 652 N.E.2d 811 (Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Plaintiff argues that Williamson County owed decedents a duty of care pursuant to section 3‑102(a) of the Local Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act… Wagner made clear that if the governmental entity breaches its duty to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition, even a negligent plaintiff may recover to the extent permitted under principles of comparative negligence.”
